Derek James wrote:

>We've actually done a little testing both ways, and it doesn't appear
>to make much of a difference...which I think tends to confirm that
>NEAT is overall a very robust algorithm.
>  
>
Given these facts it seems highly likely that my initial random 
population of neat parameters will all perform about the same and that 
there will be no clear winners, but that in itself will be a 
confirmation of your (and other's) observations. And there is a small 
chance of finding some posive results, or perhaps identifying some bad 
parameter combinations that we should avoid.

>
>Well good luck with that, and let us know how it turns out. :)
>  
>
Will do.

>It's interesting, as Yuri points out, you've got parameters for your
>meta-mutations, which I suppose you could have a meta-mutation system
>for as well.  And one for that one...it's turtles all the way down!
>  
>
Maybe I should get NEAT to search for a network that can give us the 
optimal meta-parameters given the NEAT problem domain we are trying to 
solve, err, I can smell burning, I think it's my brain :(
No doubt the answer would be 42 (is Hitchhikers Guide internationally 
known?)

Colin.
